title: Clawing holes in NAT with UPnP
short_summary: This article discusses a technique to exploit UPnP functionality in NAT devices to gain unauthorized access to internal networks. It details the implementation of a web-based attack that allows an attacker to open ports on a victim's router, enabling direct communication with devices behind NAT.
summary:
The article presents a method for exploiting Universal Plug and Play (UPnP) to bypass Network Address Translation (NAT) security measures. The author explains how attackers can craft a malicious website that, when visited by a victim, causes their router to open specific ports, allowing the attacker to connect directly to devices on the victim's internal network. The paper provides a detailed breakdown of the implementation, including the use of various protocols such as the IRC DCC for data transfer, Java applets for obtaining the victim's local IP address, and HTML forms for submitting the crafted payloads. The author emphasizes the importance of understanding NAT and UPnP to appreciate the vulnerabilities that can be exploited through this technique.

The implementation details include using JavaScript to automate the submission of malicious payloads and a Python script to set up a listener on the attacker's server. The article serves as both a technical guide for executing the attack and a warning about the security implications of UPnP being enabled by default on many consumer routers. The author concludes by providing source code and references for further reading, highlighting the need for better security practices in home networking devices.
